content:
As they walked, Tommy and David chatted about their experiences with bullying, both past and present. Tommy opened up about some of the things he had been through and how hard it was to feel like no one understood him. David listened carefully, nodding sympathetically as Tommy spoke.

"I know it's hard, son," David said. "But you're not alone. I've been there too. It may seem like things will never get better, but they will. You just have to keep pushing through."

Tommy smiled weakly, grateful for his dad's support. "Thanks, dad," he said. "It's just nice to know that someone else understands."

They continued to talk, sharing stories about their childhoods and the struggles they had faced. Tommy was surprised to learn that his dad had also been bullied when he was young. He had always thought of his dad as strong and invincible, but now he saw him in a different light.

As they turned onto their street, Tommy felt a newfound sense of closeness with his dad. He knew that they still had their own battles to fight, but he also knew that they could face them together.

"I'm glad we talked, dad," Tommy said. "I feel like we understand each other better now."

David smiled, putting an arm around his son's shoulder. "Me too, son," he said. "I love you."

"I love you too, dad," Tommy replied, feeling a lump form in his throat.

They walked the rest of the way home in silence, both lost in their own thoughts. Tommy knew that he still had a lot to learn about his dad, but he was grateful for this newfound connection they had. It gave him hope that they could face anything together.
